item.title: Need for Speed Turns 30: The Lasting Legacy of EAâ€™s Fastest Franchise
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/need-for-speed-turns-30-the-lasting-legacy-of-eas-fastest-franchise

Itâ€™s December 1994. The Santa Clause, Miracle on 34th Street, Pulp Fiction, and Forrest Gump are duking it out at the global box office. Boyz II Menâ€™s On Bended Knee is about to (temporarily) cede the number one spot on the Billboard Hot 100 to Here Comes the Hotstepper by lyrical gangster Ini Kamoze. In video games, the original PlayStation has just launched in Japan.

But forget the PlayStation for a moment, because December 1994 also marked the arrival of another interactive icon: The Need for Speed, on the ill-fated 3DO home game console. The 3DO, despite being lauded as Time Magazineâ€™s 1993 Product of the Year, was ultimately a flop. There was no '3DO II'. The Need for Speed, however, was not a flop. There was a Need for Speed II. And III. And a fourth, fifth, sixth, and so on.

In fact, 30 years later the Need for Speed series is still with us.

And itâ€™s become one of the best-selling game series of all time.

3DOh Yeah

â€œNeed for Speed is actually one of the most successful game franchises ever,â€ notes Criterion Senior Creative Director John Stanley. Stanley has been with Criterion for 14 years working across multiple EA series, from Battlefield to Battlefront, but his predominant focus is Need for Speed. â€œSo itâ€™s a very big honour and mantle to be lifted each time.â€

15 years ago, sales figures for the franchise hit 100 million copies. A decade ago theyâ€™d rocketed past 150 million. Precisely what they sit at today is not known, but whatâ€™s clear is Need for Speedâ€™s success and longevity make it a monster within the racing genre.

Need for Speed is actually one of the most successful game franchises ever.

It certainly got off to a flying start. The original Need for Speed was an immediate critical hit, despite the 3DOâ€™s own particular woes. Fortunately, subsequent ports to PC, PlayStation, and Sega Saturn would go on to make The Need for Speed a commercial smash as well.

Presented by Road & Track Magazine and developed by EA Canada, The Need for Speedâ€™s 3DO debut boasted just eight cars â€“ a modest mix of European exotics and 1990s sports icons from the US and Japan. It also featured a total of three tracks. Yes, thatâ€™s paltry by later standards, but itâ€™s worth keeping in mind that this was entirely typical for the time â€“ at least, until the original Gran Turismo arrived several years later with a garage pumped up to unprecedented proportions.

Itâ€™s also important to note that EA Canada had previously been known as Distinctive Software. Prior to its acquisition by EA in the early â€™90s, Distinctive Software was responsible for the influential original Test Drive, its follow-up The Duel: Test Drive II, and cult, early 3D racing favourite Stunts (known as 4D Sports Driving in some regions). That high-speed experience was abundantly evident in The Need for Speed. Like the early Test Drive games that came before it, The Need for Speed asked players to dodge traffic as fast as they dared while outrunning the pursuing police. Electronic Gaming Monthly called it â€œthe racing game to beat on the 3DO.â€ Edge Magazine declared it featured â€œthe richest 3D environment ever seen on a home system.â€ GamePro was similarly full of praise, positing that â€œ[i]f you dream of racing exotic sports cars, it doesnâ€™t get any better than this incredible game.â€

Raising the (High) Stakes

Of course, it did get better. Need for Speed built itself into a true racing juggernaut throughout the remainder of the â€™90s, and it lapped Test Drive as the premier purveyor of playable police pursuits and illegal street racing. The series became the place to find the greatest exotics of the era: the Lamborghini Diablo and Ferrari 512TR. The Jaguar XJ220 and McLaren F1. Down in my own native Australia, the games were even localised with their own, regional-exclusive covers, and injected with the hottest homegrown sports sedans of the time. That was truly something, as a teenager; to be stalking a games store and see the sickest Australian cars on the street staring back at me from the shelves. That was unique to Need for Speed during this era.

But perhaps more than anything, Need for Speed carved itself out a reputation as a series that celebrated not just racing, but risk.

â€œI argue itâ€™s the forerunner, or has been and still is the forerunner, in the only franchise really delivering on consequence,â€ says Stanley. â€œThat thrill of the chase. I think nothing else out there in the racing game genre does that.â€

By asking people to outrun police, and eventually even place their pink slips on the line, Need for Speed was a series that pushed its players to take risks. For clarity, by the time Need for Speed came around, weâ€™d admittedly already faced the long arm of the law in 1987â€™s Test Drive, and many of us wouldâ€™ve already lost rides to rivals after racing for slips in 1989â€™s Street Rod. But even if it wasnâ€™t the first, Need for Speed was an extremely early adopter of these philosophies of risk â€“ and it certainly became the most recognisable.

Tuna, No Crust

As the years went on, the property eventually found itself taking risks of its own. Firstly, with 2003â€™s radically reinvented Need for Speed: Underground, and then with 2005â€™s Need for Speed: Most Wanted â€“ which is still the best selling game in the whole series.

â€œOh man, theyâ€™re my beloved,â€ grins Justin Wiebe, who jokingly describes himself as the â€œold fossilâ€ EA dug up for this chat. Currently Studio Design Director at Ripple Effect, Wiebeâ€™s history with the Need for Speed series dates back to Hot Pursuit 2 in 2002.

â€œTheyâ€™re like my crown jewels, to be honest with you,â€ he continues. â€œIâ€™ve had a long career here and boy am I proud of having a chance to work on those games.â€

On Underground, Wiebe explains the team didnâ€™t quite know what they had on their hands at the time, but they were all hooked.

â€œIt was so addictive to play,â€ he says. â€œIt was the introduction of things like drag racing for the first time, where it was a completely new way of playing at high speed. And we were starting to explore other new, emerging racing genres â€“ like drift racing and stuff like that â€“ and starting to bring all of these new and cutting edge ideas, and then mixing in customisation. We were pioneering at that time.â€

EA followed Underground with a direct, open-world sequel â€“ the first open world in the series â€“ but the bigger question was where to take it next.

â€œWe kept asking ourselves, â€˜Well, what do we do now? How do we one-up this? What are we gonna do?â€™â€ says Wiebe. â€œAnd we had an exceptional executive producer at that time, Mike [Mann], who came in and he basically said, â€˜I want to make it the most elicit experience that weâ€™ve done to date. I want to bring in the cops, and I want to make them feel so threatening, like they are the real world.â€™â€

So that was the mandate to me: take these cops and make everyone absolutely terrified of them.

â€œSo that was the mandate to me: take these cops and make everyone absolutely terrified of them.â€™ And I said, â€˜Then, Mike, I gotta take away peopleâ€™s cars that they earned; Iâ€™m gonna impound them, and theyâ€™re gonna lose them for a while.â€™ And heâ€™s, like, â€˜Do it.â€™

â€œ[Need for Speed is] a franchise which is big, but itâ€™s also unafraid to try to take risks. To do things differently. To challenge the norm. And thatâ€™s what I love about working on the franchise.â€

In an entertaining twist, Wiebe even found himself in Need for Speed: Most Wanted as the racer Taz â€“ number 14 on the Blacklist â€“ after one of the actors failed to show up for a photoshoot.

â€œThey started wandering around the office trying to see, like, â€˜Whoâ€™s the most shifty-looking person we have here?â€™, and then theyâ€™re, like, â€˜You!â€™â€ chuckles Wiebe, stabbing his finger in the air. â€œSo yeah, they just grabbed me and did a couple of shots and there I am. It was a good time.â€

According to Stanley, within the corridors of Criterion, Most Wanted remains a revered example of the series at the peak of its power.

â€œI cite Most Wanted so much within the studio,â€ he says. â€œJust around the way that it managed to weave together the narrative, the gameplay, the progression. Everything comes together in this.â€

â€œA term that I use a lot, and now Iâ€™ll have to drink a shot for this: ludonarrative harmony. Because actually executing on that in a game? So important. And Most Wanted is a masterclass in that, and something that I definitely cite a lot.â€

On: The Run

Itâ€™s been almost two decades since Need for Speed: Most Wanted, and the series has continued to evolve.

â€œIf you look at it, Need for Speedâ€™s never remained the same,â€ says Criterion Producer Patrick Honnoraty, whoâ€™s worked on every Need for Speed since 2012 â€“ from Criterion to Ghost and back to Criterion. â€œFrom one iteration to the next, itâ€™s always had something that was different.â€

â€œFor good and for bad â€“ because those things donâ€™t always work and they donâ€™t always resonate with players â€“ but we guarantee that weâ€™ll always be doing something different.â€

Things donâ€™t always work and they donâ€™t always resonate with players â€“ but we guarantee that weâ€™ll always be doing something different.

â€œâ€˜For good and for badâ€™ is a great example,â€ says Wiebe. â€œFor example, my experience on creating Need for Speed: The Run. We really tried to break some new ground there. We talked about getting out of the car, and we had all these grandiose visions for how it was going to be more than just racing; the characterâ€™s going to get out of the car. But then we realised very quickly, â€˜Well, we canâ€™t really do thatâ€™, so we introduced some quicktime events.â€

â€œYeah, we all love quicktime events, right?â€ he adds with an ironic smile.

However, Wiebe believes they ultimately created â€œa grand racing adventure.â€

â€œWe wanted it to feel like your life is on the line,â€ he says. â€œThat itâ€™s more humanised than ever before about the character and the story that theyâ€™re in, racing from coast to coast. Iâ€™ll be the first to stand up and say that didnâ€™t really work, but Iâ€™m proud of the fact that we tried it.â€

â€œI was actually on a fan forum a few months ago and I actually was shocked at how highly-rated some of the fans actually made that game. I had thought, â€˜Well, thatâ€™s a bit of a lump of coal in my resume.â€™ But it turns out that it actually has a massive cult following, and there are certain people that absolutely adore that game. And that brought a little joy to my heart; that we took a risk and there are some people that really found something to love about it.â€

That brought a little joy to my heart; that we took a risk and there are some people that really found something to love about it.

Honnoraty has noticed the same thing.

â€œI think every Need for Speed Iâ€™ve worked on, when itâ€™s come out itâ€™s been, â€˜Oh my god, it was no good; it was rubbish,â€ he says. â€œPeople didnâ€™t like it. And then years pass and itâ€™s, like, â€˜Ah, it was so good! It had these great elements to it. It was the best Need for Speed. Why donâ€™t you go and make one back like that?â€™â€

â€œNeed for Speed is always too ahead of its time, is my thing. Every time we bring one out. Every time we bring one and it doesnâ€™t strike, people look back on them so fondly.â€

Defining the Series

30 years on, building a Need for Speed game is an exponentially more complicated task than it ever was, and more challenging than ever. For Senior Vehicle Artist Frankie Yip the work required is significant, but he wouldnâ€™t have it any other way.

â€œThe cars in Need for Speed are far more intricate now compared to the earlier days of the franchise,â€ explains Yip, who has worked on the franchise for the entirety of his 20-year career in the gaming industry. After picking up a copy of Need for Speed: Underground for PlayStation 2 as a teenager, Yip got so hooked he took a 3D modelling course and was soon living his dream, making cars for Need for Speed: Underground 2.

â€œI actually thought I was going to fail in the 3D school,â€ says Yip. â€œAll the assignments? All I did was just model cars. And theyâ€™re, like, â€˜Thatâ€™s not part of the assignment.â€™ I donâ€™t care; I like cars. So my portfolio was just all cars.â€

I actually thought I was going to fail in the 3D school. All the assignments? All I did was just model cars.

According to Yip, dealing with the vast amount of content produced for each car is not as straightforward as it may seem.

â€œIâ€™ll give you an example, just to break it down,â€ he begins. â€œBodykits, for example. Say a car has three bodykit designs. Thatâ€™s three front bumpers, three rear bumpers, three sideskirts, three front fenders, so on and so on. That tallies up to 15, 20 individual parts. But allowing the player to seamlessly and smoothly mix and match those parts? Yeah, it sounds simple, but it actually involves a significant amount of work. You run into issues; like, this part doesnâ€™t fit with this. This part doesnâ€™t fit with that.â€

â€œThereâ€™s different variations in bumper widths, fender shapes, fender sizes; the list goes on. Panel lines, shut lines; nothing lines up. So, how do we make this all work? We actually have to build out every single part combination out there. You take that 15 to 20 individual parts I mentioned, and you multiply it to an additional 60, or well over a hundred. It depends on the car. Like, every car is a different shape. It is a ton of work, but what this does allow is it allows the player to have thousands of part combinations. And who doesnâ€™t want that?

â€œSo now you know why, in earlier Need for Speed titles, we just restricted the body kit to be equipped as one whole unit. But honestly, whereâ€™s the fun in that?â€

For Criterion Vehicle Art Director Bryn Alban, thereâ€™s a bigger-picture challenge; that is, what defines Need for Speed to its massive and multi-generational audience.

â€œIt means so much to so many people, and everybodyâ€™s got a different opinion as to what a good Need for Speed is,â€ says Alban, whoâ€™s been around since the days of Need for Speed: Shift and brings the experience of building his own Skylines over the past 20 years to his role on the franchise. â€œSo trying to appease everybody at all times is super difficult. Even down to the nitty gritty details of what customisation we put on our cars; itâ€™s so divisive a subject for our players that itâ€™s almost impossible for us to get it a hundred percent right, all the time.â€

â€œSo when we do get things somewhat correct, itâ€™s great. But when you see those comments where youâ€™ve missed something, it really hurts. It hurts to your core. Youâ€™re, like, â€˜Oh yeah, I forgot that we shouldâ€™ve added that to the game.â€™ So, yeah, itâ€™s really tricky and tough to get that balance of making the perfect Need for Speed, really.â€

So when we do get things somewhat correct, itâ€™s great. But when you see those comments where youâ€™ve missed something, it really hurts. It hurts to your core.

For what itâ€™s worth, Iâ€™ve been missing Australian cars in the Need for Speed series since they stopped featuring back in the early 2000s, and Alban agrees it could be time for the series to circle back and include them again.

â€œYeah, thatâ€™s a very valid point, and I think itâ€™s true that Australian cars have been underrepresented in Need for Speed in its most recent history,â€ he says. â€œI canâ€™t give you a reason why that is the case, but itâ€™s definitely something that we should take a look at in the future moving forward, to see if we can redress that balance a little bit.â€

â€œWhen you look at things like Holden, theyâ€™re very iconic within Australia,â€ adds Honnoraty. â€œTheyâ€™re very interesting things; the utes that you have. So I think those are interesting examples for us to look at. And Iâ€™m sure, Bryn, youâ€™d tell me thereâ€™s plenty of them in the drift scene as well?â€

â€œYeah, you see them crop up,â€ Alban responds with his finger clearly on the pulse. â€œI mean, just this last week thereâ€™s the Drift Matsuri thatâ€™s happening in Japan, and I saw that there were a couple of Ford Falcons over there in Japan doing their thing. So thereâ€™s definitely opportunities to tap into that, I think.â€

Itâ€™s obvious Alban knows his cars. Thereâ€™s also a fun synergy in the fact that the first Instagram video Iâ€™d watched of the very Falcons Alban is referencing features one cruising through a Tokyo tunnel to Get Low by Lil Jon & The East Side Boyz. It should go without saying that anyone who played Need for Speed: Underground has that song seared into their synapses.

To the Window, to the Wall

Need for Speed itelf has cruised both high and low over the last three decades but, while the team seems conscious that the series hasnâ€™t always been at its best, thereâ€™s a clear feeling that itâ€™s always remained faithful to being fun and approachable above all else.

â€œI think the trajectory has been bumpy, actually, in some cases,â€ admits Honnoraty. â€œBut whatâ€™s happened â€“ and I think whatâ€™s been most important â€“ is if you think about the first inception of what The Need for Speed was, it was really accessible.â€

â€œI remember going to what was probably the local video game shop, or computer shop, at the time, and me and my friends saw it on the 3DO. We were like, â€˜Whatâ€™s this?â€™ We all jumped on it, on the 3DO, and you felt badass. Being able to drive it, being chased by the cops; there wasnâ€™t an experience that was really like it at the time.

I think today the biggest challenge we face is literally the age of the franchise, and what it's been.

â€œI think itâ€™s really tried to stay true to that formula. Itâ€™s still accessible today; a lot of car racing games are not so easily accessible, so people still have the option to jump in and have fun with a Need for Speed game. It makes you feel like youâ€™re just a bad-arse... Itâ€™s really inside of the DNA; itâ€™s always there.

Rank the Need for Speed series

Rank the Need for Speed series

For Honnoraty, what makes handling Need for Speed tricky today are the side effects of how long the series has survived.

â€œI think today the biggest challenge we face is literally the age of the franchise, and what it's been,â€ Honnoraty continues. â€œItâ€™s been so many different things and appeals to so many different people.â€

â€œWe even see the debates between players: which is the best game, and why is it the best game? You look at [Underground and Most Wanted]. The divisive debate that happens between which one of those is better and why â€“ and how different they really are and what they were looking at â€“ means that we sit in a place where Need for Speed means many different things to many different people.â€

Honnoraty gives an example where, after speaking to attendees of the Need for Speed Payback booth at EA Play, some players compared the demo to Most Wanted, and others were adamant it reminded them of Underground.

â€œAnd Iâ€™m, like, â€˜How? What? Theyâ€™re completely different!â€™ he says. â€œSo I think itâ€™s just that people carry with them the feeling that they had when they played those gamesâ€¦ I think thatâ€™s the hardest thing today; itâ€™s honestly reconciling what Need of Speed means to players. And youâ€™ve seen it; when we go in one direction with something that doesnâ€™t quite work, and it doesnâ€™t appeal to certain sorts of players. Or we go in another direction, so itâ€™s a real thing that we have to tackle with, day in and day out. But John [Stanley] and I work with it constantly. We think weâ€™ve nearly cracked it, so weâ€™ll see.â€

â€œDonâ€™t forget the Porsche Unleashed crowd that would argue that that is the number one Need for Speed of all time!â€ adds Wiebe.

â€œExactly! Exactly!â€ smiles Honnoraty. â€œWe have a very vocal member in our player council thatâ€™s very vocal on Porsche Unleashed.â€

â€œAnd then the Carbon crowd, the ProStreet crowd,â€ lists Stanley.

â€œThe list goes on,â€ replies Honnoraty.

The list goes on indeed. So too, we hope, will Need for Speed.

To the window, to the wall, â€˜til the sweat drop downâ€¦ well, you get the idea.

Luke is a Senior Editor on the IGN reviews team. You can track him down on Bluesky @mrlukereilly to ask him things about stuff.

item.title: These Last Minute Video Game Deals Will Ship to You By December 25: Super Mario, Sonic, Star Wars, and More
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/the-best-deals-on-last-minute-switch-ps5-xbox-video-games-before-christmas

If you're shopping for last minute video games for the holidays, surprisingly you're not too late. There are plenty of deals on PS5, Xbox Series X, and Nintendo Switch video games that can still be delivered to you before December 25. Many (but not all) of these deals are actually as good as the ones we saw during Black Friday and Cyber Monday. They're mostly limited to retailers that have nearby retail locations like Best Buy and Target, but you should still be able to choose delivery and receive it with time to spare.

Nintendo Switch Video Game Deals (Arrives by 12/25)

PS5 and Xbox Video Game Deals (Arrives by 12/25)

Super Mario RPG

Super Mario RPG

Super Mario RPG is a remake of the 1996 SNES classic. It was one of the best games to grace the console back then amidst a sea of other incredible titles, and Nintendo did a great job of staying faithful to the game's charm and fun factor. A whole slew of improvements have been implemented to bring this game up to modern day standards, including updated visuals, music, gameplay mechanics, and several small yet welcome quality-of-life UI improvements. In our Super Mario RPG review, Tom Marks wrote that "Super Mario RPG is considered a classic for a reason, and this faithful remake makes it easy for anyone who missed it in the SNES era to see why."

Pikmin 4

Pikmin 4

Pikmin 4 for the Nintendo Switch is the latest in the Pikmin franchise and arguably the best one. Pikmin 4 is incredible, and feels like the full realization of where the Pikmin franchise started heading in Pikmin 3. It has tons of content, is insanely charming, and is just overall a blast to play. In our Pikmin 4 review, Jada Griffin wrote that "Pikmin 4 adds variety to the series' traditional gameplay by offering options other than the grab-and-throw formula of the past, and brings an extra helping of top-tier levels after the credits roll."

Super Mario Odyssey

Super Mario Odyssey

Super Mario Odyssey is still one of the best games available on Nintendo Switch. From the stunning Kingdoms to the numerous new gameplay elements, this is a title any Switch owner should have in their collection. Odyssey is best known for its Capture mechanic, which allows Mario to use Cappy and take over different enemies and objects in the environment. In our Super Mario Odyssey 10/10 review, Ryan Mccaffrey wrote that "Super Mario Odyssey is a brilliant adventure and love letter to the series that made Nintendo a household name."

Ring Fit Adventure

Ring Fit Adventure

Do you want to work out but simply don't enjoy working out? Ring Fit Adventure is one way to get around this hurdle. Ring Fit incorporates a huge variety of excellent workout exercises disguised as an RPG game. An epic adventure awaits you slaying monsters and dragons, tackling new levels, traversing different environments, acquiring powerups and skills, all the while toning your abs and burning calories. In our Ring Fit Adventure review, Jonathon Dorbush wrote that "Ring Fit Adventure is a marathon, not a sprint, just like adapting a healthy lifestyle should be. The last couple of weeks havenâ€™t altered my life or made me look like The Rock all of a sudden, but as a way of getting into (or back into, in my case) a pattern of healthy living, itâ€™s been a solid push in the right direction."

Star Wars Outlaws

Star Wars Outlaws

Star Wars: Outlaws was released only three months ago and it's already 33% off for Black Friday. Maybe Ubisoft is trying to boost sales after a lackluster launch, but that means you get to enjoy a AAA title at a great discount. IGN's Tristan Ogilvie gave it a 7/10 review, which is still good, but I've beaten the game and immensely enjoyed it, so I would have given it an 8. It definitely has an "Assassin's Creed game in a Star Wars skin" vibe, and there's nothing wrong with that.

Metaphor: Refantazio

Metaphor: ReFantazio

Metaphor: ReFantazio is the latest game from Persona 3, 4, and 5 Director Katsura Hashino and the team at Atlus' Studio Zero. For the first time since launch, you can score the game at a discount, saving $20 this Black Friday. In our 9/10 review, Michael Higham wrote that "Refining the Atlus RPG formula of weaving tough turn-based combat into compelling social sim mechanics, Metaphor: ReFantazio doesnâ€™t just send a powerful message across its political drama, it becomes a beautiful expression of the real impact storytelling can have on all of us."

Sonic X Shadow Generations

Sonic X Shadow Generations

Sonic X Shadow Generations is easily one of the best Sonic games in recent history. In our 9/10 Sonic X Shadow Generations review, Jada Griffin wrote that "Sonic X Shadow Generations takes an already excellent game and spring jumps it to new heights with a creative Shadow campaign and an appreciable graphical upgrade." This game is actually a collection of two games in one: a remaster of the 2011 Sonic Generations and - the highlight - a brand new, original campaign starring Shadow the Hedgehog.

Eric Song is the IGN commerce manager in charge of finding the best gaming and tech deals every day. When Eric isn't hunting for deals for other people at work, he's hunting for deals for himself during his free time.

item.title: Masayuki Kato, Founder of Ys and Legend of Heroes-Maker Nihon Falcom, Dies at 78
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/masayuki-kato-founder-of-ys-and-legend-of-heroes-maker-nihon-falcom-dies-at-78

Nihon Falcom under Kato's leadership pioneered the action RPG genre.

Masayuki Kato, the founder and former president of Ys and Legend of Heroes developer Nihon Falcom, died on Sunday, December 15 at the age of 78, according to an announcement from the company today.

Kato got his start as a computer technician working in the auto industry, but fell in love with personal computers and their capacity for games and entertainment. He founded Nihon Falcom in 1981 originally to publish games for Japanese personal computers in partnership with Apple, making Nihon one of the oldest video game companies still in existance today. He named his company after the Millenium Falcon from Star Wars, but with a "com" at the end for computers.

â€” ğŸ Brad ğŸ (@Baust528) December 17, 2024

Over time, Nihon Falcom under Kato's leadership became known as one of the pioneers of the action-RPG genre, beginning with Panorama Toh in 1983, Dragon Slayer in 1984, and Xanadu in 1985. Nihon Falcom gradually became a full-fledged developer in its own right, creating long-running series such as Ys and The Legend of Heroes.

The studio continued to stay in the lane of Japanese PC games for the first two decades of its history. But that changed in the early 2000s, when Nihon Falcom began working with PlayStation to bring games such as Ys I & II Complete and The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky to PlayStation devices such as the PS2 and PSP. Ever since then, the company has continued to release action RPGs cross-platform and globally with some third-party support, even more recently expanding to Nintendo platform releases.

Kato stepped down from his role as president of Nihon Falcom in 2001 as part of a larger restructure, and was succeeded by Shinji Yamazaki and, later on, the current president Toshihiro Kondo. Kato remained involved with the company as chairman of the board of directors until his death. He is credited as a producer on a number of more recent Ys and The Legend of Heroes games, including the company's most recent global release, Ys X: Nordics.
